conclusion: The light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The objects are a white dress (A), red mushrooms (C), a rock (B), and a book (D).
When the light source moves forward, it changes the angle at which light rays hit the objects.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward because the light rays will now intersect the ground further behind the objects.
The shadows will become shorter due to the light rays hitting the objects at a more perpendicular angle, reducing the elongation of the shadows.
Shadow A (White Dress) will move backward and become shorter.
Shadow B (Rock) will move backward and become shorter.
Shadow C (Mushrooms) will move backward and become shorter.
Shadow D (Book) will move backward and become shorter.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will shift backward and decrease in size when the light source moves forward.
When the light source moves forward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become shorter.
